widget.property:
This wizard will guide you through upgrading, modifying or removing an existing Ingres instance, or installing a new one.
Click Next to begin.
I accept the terms of this license agreement

Another Ingres instance of the same version has been detected on your machine
Select an option to proceed
_Modify or remove an existing Ingres instance

An older version of Ingres has been detected on your machine.
Select an option to proceed

Multiple instances of Ingres have been detected on your machine.
Select an option to proceed
_Modify or remove an existing Ingres instance
Ingres supports multiple instances installed on the same server. Each instance is uniquely identified by an instance name.
The following instances have been detected, please select the instance you wish to modify.
_Automatically upgrade all user databases in the selected instance

All user databases must be upgraded before they can be accessed by the upgraded binaries. By default this is done automatically by the upgrade process. If you do not want this to be done now uncheck this option.
NOTE: You will have to run upgradedb manually on all user datatbases if this option is unchecked
Add or remove components from the selected instance
Remove all installed components for the selected instance. NOTE: Database, configuration and other generated files will NOT be removed.

Ingres Intelligent DBMS
The Ingres Intelligent DBMS, the foundation of the Ingres product line, provides the power to manage today's critical information resources: data, knowledge, and objects. Because of this unique ability, the Ingres Intelligent DBMS empowers organizations to model all aspects of their operations within the database engine itself, rather than within client application code.
The Ingres Intelligent DBMS can support a wide range of applications, from ad hoc queries to large-scale, mission-critical production applications which require 24-hour-a-day, 7-day-a-week service. The Ingres Intelligent DBMS features a threaded, multi-server architecture which can fully harness the power of today's scalable multiprocessors. Other advanced features include the industry's most advanced statistically based query optimizer, compiled database procedures, on-line backup, and transparent two-phase commit.

Ingres Client
The Ingres Client extension enables communication between Ingres installations in a heterogeneous, networked environment. Ingres Client supports several major protocols, including TCP/IP, ISO X.25, DEC/NET, Asynchronous, ISO/OSLAN, SNA/LU6.2, SPX, and TCP /WOLLONGONG.
Ingres Data Access Server
The Ingres Data Access Server will replace the existing JDBC server and will provide DBMS access to the existing EDBC JDBC driver, the new Ingres JDBC driver and the .NET Data Provider The Ingres Data Access Server supports several major protocols, including TCP/IP, ISO X.25, DEC/NET, Asynchronous, ISO/OSLAN, SNA/LU6.2, SPX, and TCP/WOLLONGONG.

Ingres ODBC Driver
The Ingres ODBC driver requires a third-party ODBC driver manager. The Ingres ODBC driver connects to local or remote databases to fetch or modify information.
The iiodbcadmn utility allows Linux, Unix or VMS users to configure ODBC data source information.

Ingres Replicator
The Ingres Replicator is an extension to the Ingres Intelligent DBMS server which allows data in multiple independent databases to be maintained in a synchronized manner as if contained in a single, centralized relational database. In this way, Ingres Replicator provides client applications with almost transparent access to enterprise-wide data.
In addition to supporting access to Ingres databases, Ingres Replicator can integrate data from other database systems, with the addition of Ingres Client and Enterprise Access extensions. In combination, these Ingres products allow replication to a wide variety of database systems: IBM DB2, IBM IMS, IBM ISAM, IBM VSAM, DEC RMS, DEC Rdb, and HP data in ALLBASE/SQL or TurboIMAGE/XL.

Application-By-Forms
Ingres Application-By-Forms is a forms-based application development tool that allows developers to use, write, compile, and link Ingres 4GL (formerly OpenINGRES/4GL) programs.
Vision
Ingres Vision is the premier tool for rapid development of open, portable, character-based applications. Vision combines the productivity of a 4GL, the production power of a 3GL, an advanced user interface, automatic code generation capabilities, and customizable code templates which allow rapid development of applications that run against relational and non-relational database systems from Ingres Corporation, IBM, DEC, and Hewlett Packard. Vision applications can be deployed both as traditional, host-based terminal applications, or as client-server applications under Microsoft Windows, OS/2, MS-DOS, Unix, Linux and VMS. When deployed under MS Windows and IBM Presentation Manager, Vision applications support pull-down menus, button bars, and other mouse-driven graphical user interface features.

Ingres Star Distributed DBMS
The Ingres Star Distributed DBMS is a distributed extension to the Ingres Intelligent DBMS server which allows data from multiple independent databases to be accessed as if contained in a single, centralized relational database. In this way, Ingres Star provides client applications with transparent access to enterprise-wide data.
In addition to supporting access to Ingres databases, Ingres Star can seamlessly integrate data from other database systems, with the addition of Ingres Client and Enterprise Access extensions. In combination, these Ingres products allow seamless, distributed access to data stored in a wide variety of database systems: IBM DB2, IBM IMS, IBM ISAM, IBM VSAM, DEC RMS, DEC Rdb, and HP data in ALLBASE/SQL or TurboIMAGE/XL.
Define the database file locations. To accept the defaults, simply click next.

Ingres Location Variables
The Ingres storage locations and the corresponding Ingres variables are listed below:
Ingres Location Variables II_DATABASE Default location for database files II_CHECKPOINT Default location for full backup snapshots II_JOURNAL Default location for journals (backup audit trails) II_DUMP Default location for on-line backup change logs II_WORK Default location for temporary files
Important Note
You cannot change the values you assign to the default Ingres storage location variables once this setup procedure has been completed. However you can create additional storage locations and assign individual databases to them.
ALL locations MUST exist and be writable by the instance owner. If this user does not exist the location MUST be globally writable. If it is not, installation of the DBMS package will fail.
For information on creating storage locations, refer to the Ingres Database Administrator's Guide.

The Default Database Location
The Ingres variable II_DATABASE stores the default location used to store Ingres database files.
Once a value has been assigned to II_DATABASE, you can change it only by removing and re-installing Ingres. Refer to the Ingres Database Administrator's Guide for information on moving the default database file location.
NOTE: This location must exist and be writable by the instance owner.

The Default Backup, Journal and Dump Locations
The Ingres variables II_CHECKPOINT, II_JOURNAL, and II_DUMP are used to store the default locations used for full and incremental on-line backup files. It is essential that II_CHECKPOINT, II_JOURNAL and II_DUMP not be assigned to the same physical device as II_DATABASE. If this restriction is ignored, you will be unable to recover lost data in the event that the II_DATABASE location fails.
Once assigned, the values of II_CHECKPOINT, II_JOURNAL, and II_DUMP can only be changed by removing and re-installing Ingres. Refer to the Ingres Database Administrator's Guide for information on moving the default backup locations.
Refer to the chapter on "Backup and Recovery" in the Ingres Database Administrator's Guide for instructions on backup and recovery of Ingres databases.
NOTE: This location must exist and be writable by the instance owner.

The Default Backup, Journal and Dump Locations
The Ingres variables II_CHECKPOINT, II_JOURNAL, and II_DUMP are used to store the default locations used for full and incremental on-line backup files. It is essential that II_CHECKPOINT, II_JOURNAL and II_DUMP not be assigned to the same physical device as II_DATABASE. If this restriction is ignored, you will be unable to recover lost data in the event that the II_DATABASE location fails.
Once assigned, the values of II_CHECKPOINT, II_JOURNAL, and II_DUMP can only be changed by removing and re-installing Ingres. Refer to the Ingres Database Administrator's Guide for information on moving the default backup locations.
Refer to the chapter on "Backup and Recovery" in the Ingres Database Administrator's Guide for instructions on backup and recovery of Ingres databases.
NOTE: This location must exist and be writable by the instance owner.

The Default Backup, Journal and Dump Locations
The Ingres variables II_CHECKPOINT, II_JOURNAL, and II_DUMP are used to store the default locations used for full and incremental on-line backup files. It is essential that II_CHECKPOINT, II_JOURNAL and II_DUMP not be assigned to the same physical device as II_DATABASE. If this restriction is ignored, you will be unable to recover lost data in the event that the II_DATABASE location fails.
Once assigned, the values of II_CHECKPOINT, II_JOURNAL, and II_DUMP can only be changed by removing and re-installing Ingres. Refer to the Ingres Database Administrator's Guide for information on moving the default backup locations.
Refer to the chapter on "Backup and Recovery" in the Ingres Database Administrator's Guide for instructions on backup and recovery of Ingres databases.
NOTE: This location must exist and be writable by the instance owner.

The Default Temporary Work Location
The Ingres variable II_WORK stores the default location used for all temporary files created during external sorts and other DBMS server operations that require large amounts of temporary file space. Ingres lets you designate a separate storage device as the default location for these files.
When choosing the II_WORK location, be aware that temporary files tend to increase fragmentation on storage devices, which can lead to decreased performance. For this reason, you should assign II_WORK to a physical device which does not contain database, checkpoint, journal, or dump files, if possible. Your choice of the default work location does not affect your ability to recover lost data in the event of a storage device failure, although it may affect performance.
Once assigned, the value of II_WORK can only be changed by removing and re-installing Ingres. Refer to the Ingres Database Administrator's Guide for instructions on moving the default work location in this manner.
NOTE: This location must exist and be writable by the instance owner.
Define the transaction log file size and locations.

Ingres Transaction Log File
The Ingres Intelligent DBMS uses a circular transaction log file to store uncommitted transactions and buffer committed transactions before they are written to the database file location(s).
The size of the transaction log needed for a particular instance is highly dependent on the frequency, type and size of transactions being processed. For this reason, unless you are sure you require a larger transaction log file, we recommend accepting the default and changing it later if required.
The size of the transaction log file can be changed after installation using cbf or vcbf.
See the Database Administrator Guide for more details.

Ingres Transaction Log File
The Ingres Intelligent DBMS uses a circular transaction log file to store uncommitted transactions and buffer committed transactions before they are written to the database file location(s).
ALL log locations MUST exist and be writable by the instance owner. If this user does not exist the location MUST be globally writable. If it is not, installation of the DBMS package will fail.
By default, Ingres will NOT maintain a backup of the primary transaction log file on the storage location which you select.

Dual Logging
In order to guarantee that no committed transactions can be lost in the event of a single storage device failure, a secondary Ingres transaction log can be maintained on a storage device which is independent of the primary transaction log file device.
You have the option of enabling a secondary transaction log file, although you should only do so if the location you intend to use for your secondary transaction log file is different from the location used for your primary log.
Note: We recommend the transaction log and the dual transaction log be stored on different physical devices.

SQL92 Compliance
The Ingres DBMS can be configured to be strictly compliant with the ANSI/ISO entry-level SQL-92 standard. If you need information about this standard, please refer to the Ingres SQL Reference Manual.
Strict ANSI/ISO SQL-92 compliance causes some Ingres features to operate in a non-default mode, such as uppercase identifiers and subquery semantics changes. Strict compliance should only be selected if you are sure that you require it.
Note: Strict compliance should only be selected if you are sure you require it. It is not recommended for normal operation.

Date Type Alias
Ingres supports the ANSI date and time data types DATE, TIME, TIMESTAMP, and INTERVAL. Previously, Ingres supported one date data type that could store dates, times, intervals, and time stamps. The previous date type has been renamed to INGRESDATE.
The configuration parameter date_alias controls whether the keyword DATE used for a column data type refers to INGRESDATE or to ANSIDATE. (See the Ingres Release Summary for more info)

Create a demonstration database named demodb and populate it with a tables, view, procedures and other database objects. The database is used by Ingres demonstration applications such as the Ingres Frequent Flyer Demo.
Create a folder containing Ingres stuff on your desktop
Create and populate a demonstration database called demodb
You are now ready to upgrade your Ingres instance.
Please wait while the Ingres instance is upgraded

The Ingres "Lauch Pad" is GUI utility designed to assist you in getting started with Ingres. It will show you what's new in this release, help you with database administration or developing an application or just point you to the documentation

An error occured during installation and the process was unable to complete.
Review the errors below and contact Ingres technical support at http://www.ingres.com/support for further assistance.
To exit click "Finish"

This wizard will guide you through creating an Ingres installer response file
Click 'Next' to begin.
Welcome to the Ingres Response File Generator
Select the platform you want to create a response file for
A response file will be created for deploying Ingres on Linux
A response file will be created for deploying Ingres on Windows
Simple, default configuration for those new to Ingres
Simple, default configuration for those new to Ingres

This wizard will guide you through installing and settting up Ingres.
Click 'Next' to begin.
I accept the terms of this license agreement
Select a configuration type from the list below
Transactional System Optimized for transaction-oriented appliancations, such as ERP or CRM systems, electrontic banking, order processing, time clock system, and e-commerce systems.
Business Intelligence System Optimized for business decision making; reporting, analytics, data mining, business performance management, decision support and predictive analytics
Content Management System Optimized for storing, controlling, versioning, and publishing information including files, image media, audio, video, electronic documents, and web content

Traditional Ingres System High transaction isolation, low concurrency as if transactions are executed serially, rather than concurrently. This level requires transaction retries in the event of serialization failures. Use this setting for client-only installations.
Simple, default configuration for those new to Ingres
For experienced Ingres users and custom installation
A default instance will be created. You will have the opportunity to select the components to be installed.
A custom instance will be created. You will have greater control over the installed components and configuration options available.
Ingres supports multiple instances installed on the same machine. Each instance is uniquely identified by an instance name.
Specify a custom name or accept the default

Instance Name
Enter a two character string to complete the instance name. The first character must be an UPPER case letter and the second can be a number or an UPPER case letter
Select the set of components to install.
Manually select features you wish to install
Manually select the components to be installed
Components most commonly used for an Ingres client will be installed
Components most commonly used for an Ingres server will be installed
All Ingres components will be installed

Define the installation locations and database file locations. To accept the defaults, simply click next.
Location where Ingres will be installed
This value is stored in the environment variable _II__SYSTEM

The Ingres storage locations and the corresponding Ingres variables are listed below:
Ingres Location Variables II_DATABASE Default location for database files II_CHECKPOINT Default location for full backup snapshots II_JOURNAL Default location for journals (backup audit trails) II_DUMP Default location for on-line backup change logs II_WORK Default location for temporary files
Important Note
You cannot change the values you assign to the default Ingres storage location variables once this setup procedure has been completed. However you can create additional storage locations and assign individual databases to them.
ALL locations MUST exist and be writable by the instance owner. If this user does not exist the location MUST be globally writable. If it is not, installation of the DBMS package will fail.
For information on creating storage locations, refer to the Ingres Database Administrator's Guide.

The Ingres variable II_DATABASE stores the default location used to store Ingres database files.
Once a value has been assigned to II_DATABASE, you can change it only by removing and re-installing Ingres. Refer to the Ingres Database Administrator's Guide for information on moving the default database file location.
NOTE: This location must exist and be writable by the instance owner.

It is essential that II_CHECKPOINT, II_JOURNAL and II_DUMP not be assigned to the same physical device as II_DATABASE. When choosing the II_WORK location, be aware that temporary files tend to increase fragmentation on storage devices, which can lead to decreased performance. Your choice of the default work location does not affect your ability to recover lost data in the event of a storage device failure, although it may affect performance.

Vectorwise specific option can be configured here. To accept the default values, simply click next
Location where Ingres will be installed
Click check-box to change values from default
Click check-box to change values from default
Define the transaction log file size and locations.

Ingres Transaction Log File
The Ingres Intelligent DBMS uses a circular transaction log file to store uncommitted transactions and buffer committed transactions before they are written to the database file location(s).
The size of the transaction log needed for a particular instance is highly dependent on the frequency, type and size of transactions being processed. For this reason, unless you are sure you require a larger transaction log file, we recommend accepting the default and changing it later if required.
The size of the transaction log file can be changed after installation using cbf or vcbf.
See the Database Administrator Guide for more details.

Ingres Transaction Log File
The Ingres Intelligent DBMS uses a circular transaction log file to store uncommitted transactions and buffer committed transactions before they are written to the database file location(s).
ALL log locations MUST exist and be writable by the instance owner. If this user does not exist the location MUST be globally writable. If it is not, installation of the DBMS package will fail.
By default, Ingres will NOT maintain a backup of the primary transaction log file on the storage location which you select.

Dual Logging
In order to guarantee that no committed transactions can be lost in the event of a single storage device failure, a secondary Ingres transaction log can be maintained on a storage device which is independent of the primary transaction log file device.
You have the option of enabling a secondary transaction log file, although you should only do so if the location you intend to use for your secondary transaction log file is different from the location used for your primary log.

Ingres Dual Transaction Log Location
The location used for the dual transaction log file. This is a secondary location for storing uncommitted transactions. It is written to in parallel with the primary log file and used as a hot "stand-by" in the event of device or other catastrophic failure.
Note: We recommend the transaction log and the dual transaction log be stored on different physical devices.

Timezone Info
You must now specify the time zone this installation is located in. To specify a time zone, you must first select the region of the world this installation is located in. You will then be prompted with a list of the time zones in that region.

Character Set
Ingres supports different character sets. You must now enter the character set you want to use with this Ingres installation.
IMPORTANT NOTE: You will be unable to change character sets once you make your selection. If you are unsure of which character set to use, exit this program and refer to the Ingres Getting Started Guide.

SQL92 Compliance
The Ingres DBMS can be configured to be strictly compliant with the ANSI/ISO entry-level SQL-92 standard. If you need information about this standard, please refer to the Ingres SQL Reference Manual.
Strict ANSI/ISO SQL-92 compliance causes some Ingres features to operate in a non-default mode, such as uppercase identifiers and subquery semantics changes. Strict compliance should only be selected if you are sure that you require it.
Note: Strict compliance should only be selected if you are sure you require it. It is not recommended for normal operation.

Date Type Alias
Ingres supports the ANSI date and time data types DATE, TIME, TIMESTAMP, and INTERVAL. Previously, Ingres supported one date data type that could store dates, times, intervals, and time stamps. The previous date type has been renamed to INGRESDATE.
The configuration parameter date_alias controls whether the keyword DATE used for a column data type refers to INGRESDATE or to ANSIDATE. (See the Ingres Release Summary for more info)
Select the user account & group that will own the instance

By default the Ingres instance and all the files associated with it will be owned by the OS user ingres. If you want it owned by a different OS user, enter the username here. The user will be created if it doesn't already exist.
This user will also be made a member of the ingres user group. If you want it to be part of a different user group, enter the group name here. The group will be created if it doesn't already exist.

Create a demonstration database named demodb and populate it with a tables, view, procedures and other database objects. The database is used by Ingres demonstration applications such as the Ingres Frequent Flyer Demo.
Your Ingres instance will be configured to startup and shutdown with your system. If you want to start and stop Ingres independently of your computer, uncheck this option.
Your Ingres instance will be configured to startup and shutdown with your system. If you want to start and stop Ingres independently of your computer, uncheck this option.
Adds the directory containing the Ingres executables to the Windows path variable. You can then run Ingres executables from the command line
Adds the directory containing the Ingres executables to the Windows path variable. You can then run Ingres executables from the command line
Create a populated demonstration database named demodb
Create and populate a demonstration database called demodb
Start Ingres when your computer starts up
You are now ready to install Ingres. Review your settings below and click Install to proceed with the installation.
Ingres has been successfully installed. To exit click "Finish"

The Ingres "Lauch Pad" is GUI utility designed to assist you in getting started with Ingres. It will show you what's new in this release, help you with database administration or developing an application or just point you to the documentation

Review the errors below and contact Ingres technical support at http://www.ingres.com/support for further assistance.

You are now ready to generate a respose file. Review your settings below and click Next to proceed.
The response file has been successfully. To change your setting click "Back" To write it to a file click "Save" To exit click "Finish"
